item.title: Gmail to Let Users Change Their Addresses While Keeping Data
item.description: Under the shift, which Google said would eventually be rolled out to all users, old addresses would remain active. Messages and services would not be lost.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
item.media:description: Google has quietly started to roll out a way for users to change their Gmail addresses ending with @gmail.com, and keep all their emails.

item.title: What America Might Look Like With Zero Immigration
item.description: The Trump administration’s efforts to reduce the foreign-born population are being felt in hospitals and soccer leagues and on Main Streets across the country, with hints of what’s to come.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: KC McGinnis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The foreign-born population in the United States hit a new high in 2024. Immigration has changed places like Marshalltown, Iowa, where some 50 dialects are spoken in the public schools.

item.title: Can You Reboot a Lamp Like a Superhero Franchise?
item.description: Riding an endless wave of nostalgia, one company is exhuming the intellectual property of midcentury designers to create new audiences for forgotten work.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Mathias Eis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Masiello saw a business opportunity in licensing furniture designs. He’s holding a model of a chair by the Danish designer Steen Ostergaard.

item.title: Guinea Goes to Polls as Ruling Junta Seeks Legitimacy
item.description: Whoever wins faces the daunting task of feeding the West African country’s poor and navigating the interests of global powers seeking critical minerals, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Patrick Meinhardt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A supporter dressed as Mamady Doumbouya traveling with armed escorts in Conakry, Guinea, on Thursday.

item.title: Hundreds of Flights Canceled at New York Airports, Even With a Few Inches of Snow
item.description: To avoid the ripple effects of real-time adjustments to what was predicted to be up to nine inches of snow, the major airlines said they pre-emptively canceled flights.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Gabe Castro-Root/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kennedy International Airport on Saturday morning. The airport, along with LaGuardia and Newark International, dealt with hundreds of flight cancellations and delays from Friday into Saturday.

item.title: More Student Loan Borrowers Are Shedding Debts in Bankruptcy
item.description: A new study suggests that distressed borrowers using a simpler bankruptcy process are succeeding — and that more people like them should try.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amy Howdyshell, 43, used a bankruptcy filing to get more than $78,000 in federal student debt dismissed.

item.title: Before Electric Vehicles Became Political, There Was the Toyota Prius
item.description: The political polarization of battery-powered cars may have started when Toyota released its first hybrid model 25 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Ulrich
item.media:credit: Adam Riding for The New York Times
item.media:description: The marketing for the Toyota Prius may have inadvertently started the culture war around hybrid and electric vehicles by characterizing them as a way to save the planet, some experts say.

item.title: My Job Is Making Me Sick
item.description: Plus, the long-lost art of the direct confrontation.
item.dc:creator: Max Read

item.title: How One Father Created an Organ Empire
item.description: The National Kidney Registry has matched thousands of kidney donors with recipients. It has also paid millions of dollars to a company owned by its founder.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Ivory, Grace Ashford and Robert Gebeloff
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The organization, which began as a nonprofit, charges hospitals for access to its donor registry.

item.title: How Anthony Ramos, a ‘Hamilton’ Star, Spends a Day at His Brooklyn Bar
item.description: Anthony Ramos loves hanging out with customers during busy days that may find him writing a new musical, catching a friend in a show or performing in his own.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Ahmed Gaber
item.media:description: Anthony Ramos, left, is a Brooklyn-born actor who starred as John Laurens and Philip Hamilton in the original Broadway cast of Lin-Manuel Miranda’s “Hamilton.”

item.title: What Went Wrong Before Hong Kong’s Inferno
item.description: Records show how government departments played down residents’ warnings about corrupt practices and substandard materials that fueled the deadly blaze.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan and Joy Dong
item.category: Prestige Construction and Engineering Co Ltd
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong days after a fire on Nov. 26 killed 161 people and displaced thousands.

item.title: A Wealth Tax Floated in California Has Billionaires Thinking of Leaving
item.description: It’s uncertain whether the proposal will reach the statewide ballot in November, but some billionaires like Peter Thiel and Larry Page may be unwilling to take the risk.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Theodore Schleifer and Heather Knight
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Getty Images
item.media:description: Peter Thiel, a tech venture capitalist, could face a tax bill of more than $1.2 billion if the proposed wealth tax is placed on the California ballot and approved by voters.

item.title: Why Sears’s Last Great Hope Was a Promise That Never Materialized
item.description: Only five Sears stores remain in the country, with the end likely near for what was once the mightiest American retailer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Coleman-Lochner
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The hedge fund magnate Edward Lampert’s plan to turn Sears stores into dazzling mixed-use developments had attracted prominent investors.

item.title: As A.I. Companies Borrow Billions, Debt Investors Grow Wary
item.description: Artificial intelligence companies looking to raise funds are being made to pay lofty interest rates, as debt investors become cautious.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: CoreWeave, which rents data centers, is among the smaller companies bringing debt deals.

item.title: Data Center Surge Reaches India as American Tech Giants Invest Billions
item.description: Megacities in southern India are attracting enormous investments to help build artificial intelligence infrastructure to serve the world’s most data-hungry country.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Idrees Mohammed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Microsoft’s office in Bengaluru, India. The company said it would spend $17.5 billion in India on data centers and other A.I. infrastructure.

item.title: Despite Crackdown on Activism, Tech Employees Are Still Picking Fights
item.description: They increasingly see themselves as rank-and-file workers who have traditional gripes with their companies.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Tech Workers Coalition rally this month outside the Manhattan offices of Rockstar Games, the publisher of the Grand Theft Auto video game series.

item.title: All the Cameos in ‘Marty Supreme,’ From Kevin O’Leary to Tyler, the Creator
item.description: A “Shark Tank” investor, a supermarket magnate and even N.B.A. All-Stars make appearances in the table tennis comedy.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Kimmel Tells U.K. Viewers ‘Tyranny Is Booming’ in America
item.description: Chosen by a British TV station to give an “alternative” to the king’s speech, Jimmy Kimmel said it had been a great year for the U.S. “from a fascism perspective.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Channel 4
item.media:description: A photograph released by Channel 4 for Jimmy’s Kimmel’s “Alternative Christmas Message.”

item.title: Prominent Leaders Amplify Disinformation About Brown University Shooting
item.description: Prominent business and government figures spread rumors about the attack on Brown University’s campus this month, reigniting questions about accountability in online discourse.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial outside the Van Wickle Gates on the Brown University campus, where a mass shooting killed two people.

item.title: Trump Has a New Auto Loan Tax Break. Here’s Who Could Benefit.
item.description: Many Americans can take advantage of President Trump’s deduction on auto loan interest, but the tax break will provide only modest savings.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: An auto loan deduction comes at a time when the industry is struggling to adapt to President Trump’s tariffs.

item.title: Tesla Robotaxis Are Big on Wall St. but Lagging on Roads
item.description: Shares of Tesla have hit new highs on optimism about the company’s self-driving taxis. But experts say Tesla is far behind Waymo, which has a big head start.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Ariana Gomez for The New York Times

item.title: The Class Where ‘Screenagers’ Train to Navigate Social Media and A.I.
item.description: New technologies are complicating efforts to teach the scrolling generation to think critically and defensively online.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Minh Connors for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re sending these kids out into the world, and we’re supposed to have provided them skills,” said Valerie Ziegler, a San Francisco high school teacher.

item.title: Nvidia Strikes a Deal With Groq, an A.I. Chip Start-Up
item.description: Nvidia will license Groq’s technology and hire its top executives, adding to the Silicon Valley giant’s heft in artificial intelligence chips.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Ann Wang/Reuters
item.media:description: Nvidia will hire Groq’s chief executive, Jonathan Ross, and other employees after the companies reached what Groq called a “nonexclusive licensing agreement.”

item.title: Trump’s Seizures of Oil Tankers Challenge Maritime Rules and Customs
item.description: Recent U.S. actions against ships near Venezuela may embolden other countries to seize or detain ships, legal experts said.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: 2025 Planet Labs, via Reuters
item.media:description: The U.S. government seized the Skipper, an oil tanker, in the Caribbean Sea this month after obtaining a warrant from a federal court.

item.title: Crypto for Christmas? Gen Z-ers Are Cautiously Open to the Idea.
item.description: Despite recent volatility in the crypto market, younger generations are still open to receiving digital currencies as gifts.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wyatt Johnson, 22, lost money when his portfolio in Solana, a cryptocurrency, dropped by half. Despite that, he’s still open to receiving crypto as a Christmas gift.

item.title: They Seek to Curb Online Hate. The U.S. Accuses Them of Censorship.
item.description: The Trump administration said five regulators and researchers who work to tackle disinformation and abuse on the internet had been barred from entering the United States.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Christophe Petit Tesson
item.media:description: Thierry Breton, a former European commissioner, was one of five Europeans that Secretary of State Marco Rubio called “radical activists.”

item.title: Trump Administration Downplays A.I. Risks, Ignoring Economists’ Concerns
item.description: The administration has downplayed concerns — from mass job losses, to a potential financial bubble — as President Trump cheers soaring stock prices and faster growth.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: OpenAI’s Stargate, the largest data center project in the United States, in Abilene, Texas.

item.title: A Father and Son’s $108 Billion Hostile Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Larry and David Ellison didn’t always have a close relationship. Now they’re one of the most intriguing partnerships in business.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Mark Harris; Source Photographs by Sam Comen for The New York Times; Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times; Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times; Toru Yamanaka/AFP

item.title: Did We Underestimate Kate Hudson?
item.description: For years she was pigeonholed as a rom-com star. Her turn as a blue-collar mom with a love of Neil Diamond just might vault her back to the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Thea Traff

item.title: Investors Warn of ‘Rot in Private Equity’ as Funds Strike Circular Deals
item.description: Buyout firms have struggled to sell companies they own and have instead found a workaround to get cash back to clients: Selling the companies to themselves.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell
item.media:credit: Kyle Grillot/Bloomberg
item.media:description: José E. Feliciano, a founder and managing partner of Clearlake Capital.

item.title: Texas Age-Verification Law for App Stores Is Blocked, a Win for Apple and Google
item.description: A preliminary injunction in federal court cited the First Amendment, handing a win to tech companies like Apple and Google.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Texas’ App Store Accountability Act was set to take effect next month.

item.title: U.S. Bars 5 European Tech Regulators and Researchers
item.description: The Trump administration, citing “foreign censorship,” imposed travel bans on experts involved in monitoring major tech platforms.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said in a statement that five Europeans “have led organized efforts to coerce American platforms to censor, demonetize and suppress American viewpoints they oppose.”

item.title: Pulled ’60 Minutes’ Report, Briefly Streamed in Canada, Is All Over the Internet Now
item.description: At the last minute, CBS News held a segment about Venezuelan men who were deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador. It surfaced online anyway.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: CBS’s “60 Minutes” is seen by an average of 10 million viewers a week.

item.title: Student Loan Borrowers in Default Could See Wages Garnished in Early 2026
item.description: Starting the week of Jan. 7, the Education Department will begin sending notices about paycheck deductions to about 1,000 of five million borrowers in default.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
item.media:description: According to the federal government’s student aid website, up to 15 percent of a defaulted borrower’s paycheck can be taken after other deductions, such as taxes, have been made.

item.title: U.S. GDP Grew 4.3%, Surging in Third Quarter of 2025
item.description: Gross domestic product grew at a 4.3 percent annual rate, faster than the previous three months.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. economy has outperformed the bearish expectations of some experts as consumers have continued to spend.

item.title: Why the A.I. Rally (and the Bubble Talk) Could Continue Next Year
item.description: Big Tech’s huge investment in artificial intelligence is making investors nervous. But the technology continues to advance, buoying the bulls.
item.dc:creator: Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jensen Huang, C.E.O. of Nvidia, has seen his company’s value soar to more than $4 trillion on the back of investor enthusiasm for the artificial intelligence boom.

item.title: Shoppers Spent Big This Holiday Season, Despite Economic Pressures
item.description: Consumers spent 3.9 percent more from Nov. 1 to Dec. 21 this year compared with last year, according to a Mastercard report on holiday spending.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Holiday shopping figures show that spending has remained resilient, with consumers visiting stores and restaurants even as prices have risen.

item.title: YouTube Has a Firm Grip on Daytime TV
item.description: YouTube’s big streaming lead over Netflix and other competitors stems in large part to its dominance during daylight hours.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Fortunate Joaquin

item.title: Private Equity, Saddled With Investments It Can’t Sell, Loses Its Luster
item.description: As funds deliver mediocre returns and shed investors, the industry is struggling to unload 31,000 investments, an increase over this time last year.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Harvey Schwartz, chief executive of Carlyle, one of the world’s largest private equity firms, had predicted a banner year for the industry.

item.title: China Delays Plans for Mass Production of Self-Driving Cars After Accident
item.description: After years of planning for cars that would let drivers take their hands off the wheel and eyes off the road, China’s regulators have become more cautious.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.category: Guangzhou Xiaopeng Motors Technology Co Ltd (Xpeng Motors)
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Changan Automobile assembly line in May. Changan is one of only two automakers approved to conduct limited testing of self-driving taxis.

item.title: Turmoil at CBS News After Bari Weiss Pulls a ‘60 Minutes’ Segment
item.description: Several veteran correspondents questioned how Ms. Weiss, the new CBS News editor in chief, had handled the segment, after she defended her decision on a call with the newsroom.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Manhattan studios of CBS News, whose editor in chief, Bari Weiss, spoke to the newsroom on Monday about a “60 Minutes” segment she had postponed. “I held that story because it was not ready,” she said.

item.title: Epstein Victims Ask Congress to Ensure Justice Dept. Releases All Files
item.description: More than a dozen women called for congressional hearings to ensure that the Justice Department is fully complying with the Epstein Files Transparency Act.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Annabelle Gordon/Reuters
item.media:description: Jess Michaels at a news conference in November. She was among the women who signed the letter released Monday.

item.title: Did Charlie Javice’s 147-Member Legal Team Expense $529 in Gummy Bears?
item.description: JPMorgan has had to pay tens of millions in legal costs for the convicted fraudster. It wants the public to see a newly unredacted list of itemized expenses.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon/Reuters
item.media:description: Charlie Javice was found guilty of fraud in September. She has spent more than $70 million so far on her legal defense.

item.title: Agriculture Department Sheds a Fifth of Its Workers
item.description: From January to June, more than 20,000 employees out of more than 110,000 left the agency, according to a report by the agency’s inspector general.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Agriculture Department in Washington.

item.title: How U.S. Defense Industry Dodged a Rare-Earth Shortage After China’s Curbs
item.description: America’s ability to make precision-guided missiles was threatened during Trump’s tariff war. But experienced players have rescued the supply chain, for now.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display of Raytheon missiles including a Tomahawk, center, which uses magnets made with samarium, a rare earth.

item.title: Larry Ellison Personally Guarantees Paramount Bid for Warner Bros.
item.description: Mr. Ellison’s personal guarantee is meant to address concerns that the Warner Bros. Discovery’s board had expressed about Paramount’s original offer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch

item.title: China Vanke Gets Temporary Lifeline to Prevent Debt Default
item.description: Bondholders for one of China’s biggest real estate developers extended a grace period to negotiate a delayed repayment of a $285 million bond issue.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Residential buildings under construction by China Vanke, a real estate developer, in Hangzhou, last year.

item.title: Riding a High, Deal Makers Grow Bullish on 2026
item.description: It was a comeback year for I.P.O.s. and mergers and acquisitions. Wall Street is optimistic that the winning streak will continue.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: I.P.O.s had a big comeback in 2025. Figma, the design software maker, was among those to make a splashy entry in the public market.

item.title: The Economy Survived 2025, But Many Americans Are Reeling
item.description: A feared recession didn’t materialize, but unemployment rose, wage growth slowed and affordability challenges are mounting.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Ricardo Rey

item.title: Uber Clears Violent Felons to Drive
item.description: Our reporter, Emily Steel, found that in many states, Uber’s guidelines allow people with serious criminal convictions to drive, as long as those convictions are more than seven years old. Some of those drivers have gone on to sexually assault or harass passengers.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel, Christina Shaman, Zach Caldwell, David Jouppi and Thomas Trudeau
